title: Optus sent triple-zero outage notification to wrong email address
text:
Optus notified the government about its major triple-zero outage last month that led to the deaths of three people by sending two emails to the wrong address, a parliamentary committee has been told.

Addressing Senate estimates this morning, Deputy Secretary James Chisholm said Optus sent two emails about the outage on September 18 – the first at 2.45pm when it was detected, and the second seven minutes later when it was fixed — were sent to an old, out-of-date address.

The inbox wasn't monitored, so it wasn't until the next afternoon that the department found out about the outage.

Optus notified the government about its triple-zero outage by sending two emails to the wrong address. (AP Photo/Mark Baker)

"We have systems in place for notification. That requires information being sent to the right place," Chisholm said.

"That email was not even sent to the right place."

This was despite Optus using the correct email address before the outage.

"Optus had, indeed, regularly been sending outage notifications to the correct outage notification email address in all instances other than the incredibly significant outage of the 18th of September," First Assistant Secretary Samual Grunhard said.

The hearing was told the telecommunications industry had been told which address to use, and that the correct one is publicly listed on the Australian Communications and Media Authority's (ACMA) website.

9news.com.au has contacted Optus for comment.

Optus CEO Stephen Rue didn't inform the public about the outage until more than a day after it had been resolved. (Sitthixay Ditthavong)

The damning revelation comes after telco bosses, including Optus chief executive Stephen Rue, were summoned to a meeting with Communications Minister Anika Wells yesterday as she unveiled new triple-zero watchdog laws.

It also coincided with a visit to parliament by Lawrence Wong, the prime minister of Singapore, the home of Optus' parent company, Singtel.

Following a meeting with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, Wong said he expected the companies to fully cooperate with the investigation into the outage.

"I understand fully the anger, frustration and outrage at what happened… I've extended my condolences to those impacted by the outage, including the family members and loved ones of those who lost their lives, which is tragic," he told reporters.

"All I can do is to say, from a government's perspective, we expect our companies to act responsibly."

Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said he expected Singtel and Optus to fully cooperate with the investigation into the outage. (Dominic Lorrimer)

Optus had already faced heavy criticism for its handling of and response to the outage, particularly its communication about it.

The telco had initially told ACMA that it had only impacted 10 calls, and it wasn't until the day after the outage, late on Friday, September 19, that the public was informed about the issue.

Rue also admitted Optus received at least five calls to its customer service line about the outage before it was fixed.

title: The world is anxious and it's fuelling a new Australian gold rush
text:
The world is anxious and it's fuelling a new Australian gold rush.

Record prices for the rare material investors flock to amid global uncertainty are expected to push gold past gas to become our second most valuable resource export.

Gold futures are up about 50 per cent since the start of 2025, bursting through the $US4000 ($6071) per ounce mark for the first time ever this morning.

Three 1kg gold bullion bars lie on the counter in a gold dealers in the jewellery quarter in Birmingham, England. (Photo by Christopher Furlong/Getty Images/File)

Gold is expected to pull in an extra $13 billion for Australia's resources and energy exports revenue this financial year compared to 2024-25, because many of the other big hitters are plunging.

And that's a good thing because the Department of Industry, Science and Resources expects the country to make $16 billion less from these exports this financial year, even with the golden boost.

Gold exports are predicted to surge from $47 billion in 2024–25 to $60 billion this year before remaining almost steady next year, according to the September 2025 Resources and Energy Quarterly, published yesterday.

But it's only able to surpass gas because liquid natural gas prices are falling rapidly in the face of lower oil prices and more LNG supply from the US and Qatar.

The department expects a drop from $65 billion to $48 billion this year, amid five years of falling prices.

Even iron ore, the undisputed gold medallist of the sector with $116 in exports last year, is expected to take a hit, raking in $3 billion less this year and falling another $10 billion in 2026-27.

Even iron ore, the undisputed gold medallist of the sector with $116 in exports last year, is expected to take a hit. (Alex Ellinghausen)

Even though miners will be digging up more (1.4 per cent) of the material the world relies on to make steel every year, prices are expected to drop thanks to more supply from Africa and other regions.

"The discovery of gold helped build this nation and gold mining is still creating wealth and jobs for our economy today," Minister for Resources and Northern Australia Madeleine King said.

"Australia's resources and energy sector remains strong, with gold and critical minerals playing an increasingly important role in our export mix."

Gold hit a record high today. (Sven Hoppe / dpa/picture alliance / Getty)

Why are prices going up?

Gold sales can rise sharply when anxious investors seek secure investments for their money.

The asset has seen wide gains over the past year, particularly with US President Donald Trump's barrage of tariffs plunging much of the world into economic uncertainty.

Other precious metals, such as silver, have also raked in gains. S

ilver futures are up about 60 per cent, trading at close to $US48 per troy ounce on Tuesday.

Much of the recent economic turmoil has spanned from Trump's trade wars, which have pushed costs higher and weakened the US job market.

Gold sales can rise sharply when anxious investors seek secure investments for their money. (AP Photo / Frank Franklin II)

The current US government shutdown has added to anxieties among consumers and bosses.

UBS Global Wealth Management commodity analyst Giovanni Staunovo also points to continued weakness of the US dollar and renewed rate cuts from the Federal Reserve Bank.

Since mid-January, the US dollar has fallen 9 per cent against a basket of currencies, a rare and steep decline, to its lowest level in three years.

Investors traditionally dump Aussie dollars during global uncertainty but it's up more than 6 per cent against its US counterpart since the same time, while having fallen more than 6 per cent against the euro and almost 4 per cent against the pound sterling.

Gold prices have surged to a record high. (Getty)

Is gold worth the investment?

Advocates of investing in gold call it a "safe haven", arguing the commodity can serve to diversify and balance your investment portfolio, as well as mitigate possible risks down the road.

Some also take comfort in buying something tangible that has the potential to increase in value over time.

Still, experts caution against putting all your eggs in one basket.

And not everyone agrees gold is a good investment.

Critics say gold isn't always the inflation hedge many say it is – and that there are more efficient ways to protect against potential losses.

The Commodity Futures Trade Commission previously warned precious metals could be highly volatile, saying "when economic anxiety or instability is high, the people who typically profit from precious metals are the sellers".

title: Google hopes this one little tab is about to change the way you search
text:
An artificial intelligence injection that's been dubbed the biggest change to Google Search in years is coming to Australia , allowing users to ask more complex questions.

The search giant this morning announced it would be rolling out AI Mode, its "most powerful AI search experience yet", in Australia and more than 40 other countries this week.

It's just one small tab on your computer or smartphone search page but the company says it will make a big difference to search, offering something that's different to both traditional internet scouring and new chat-based AI tools.

An artificial intelligence injection that's been dubbed the biggest change to Google Search in years is coming to Australia, allowing users to ask more complex questions. (Google)

Vice president of product management Hema Budaraju said Australian users would start seeing a new tab called AI Mode alongside their standard search options.

"Once you click into that, you should be able to ask any question, literally any question on your mind, and then receive a predictable AI response that has got many ways to engage with the web, as well as the ability to ask a follow-up," she told 9News.

She used examples such as figuring out which clubs someone just starting out in golf should buy or how to handle a weird error message thrown up by a washing machine.

"How might you be able to just take a picture of that and ask, 'Hey, is this a normal error? What should I do? Can I fix this by myself? Do I need to call technician?'," she said.

"Now, remember in a world where it was very keyword driven, this would have been many, many searches and hours of agony, and now you can literally just take a picture and ask for information."

AI Mode uses what Google calls a query fan-out, meaning it analyses your natural-language or image query and breaks it off into many different queries that it knits back into an answer the company says can be both broader and deeper than a traditional search, but still accompanied by links.

Google vice president of product management Hema Budaraju. (Google)

Google gave the example of creating yourself a walking tour around Melbourne to check out specialty coffee shops, galleries and street art, then asking where you could stop for lunch and dinner along the way.

Budaraju said people were "not looking just for an AI response" but also wanted to be connected to web results they could use in a "very intuitive, simple, frictionless manner".

AI Mode is based on Google's Gemini AI models and real-time information from the search engine and can search using text, voice or photos but users can still opt for traditional searches.

Budaraju said it was distinct from the Gemini chatbot, which she said might offer more creative answers while AI Mode was more focused on finding information.

AI Mode uses what Google calls a query fan-out, meaning it analyses your query and breaks it off into many different queries that it knits back into an answer the company says can be both broader and deeper than a traditional search, but still accompanied by links. (Google)

She said more than 100 million people in the US and India had used the new search option since it rolled out there earlier this year.

Although Google's parent company Alphabet has its finger in everything from online video and email to mobile phones and self-driving cars, Search is its baby, raking in almost $US200 billion ($303 billion) a year.

That means there's a lot riding on even small changes to a product that's used trillions of times a year by billions of people.

But Google Search is facing increasing competition from large-language-model AI competitors. According to market research firm SparkToro, Google still powers 210 times more searches than ChatGPT, but the use of LLMs is growing.

An Apple executive testified earlier this year that Google searches on Apple devices' Safari browser fell for the first time in 20 years.﻿

While Google says it's put in a lot of work to make the new search feature as accurate as possible, it still warns people to double-check information for important topics.

"As with any early-stage AI product, we won't always get it right, but we are committed to continuous improvement," Budaraju wrote in a blog post published this morning.

There are also some unanswered questions around electricity and water usage and the impact AI search is having on the web.

There are also some unanswered questions around electricity and water usage and the impact AI search is having on the web. (Jessica Shapiro/AFR)

In August this year, Google said the median text-based Gemini query used about 0.00024kWh, eight times more than the commonly cited figure for a normal Google search. But that figure is from 2009 so some researchers suggest it could be much much lower thanks to advancements in computing efficiency.

"The per-prompt energy impact is equivalent to watching TV for less than nine seconds," Google said in a blog post.

"At the same time, our AI systems are becoming more efficient through research innovations and software and hardware efficiency improvements.

"For example, over a recent 12 month period, the energy and total carbon footprint of the median Gemini Apps text prompt dropped by 33x and 44x, respectively, all while delivering higher quality responses."

It's unclear how much AI Mode uses compared to a normal search or a Gemini prompt.

In terms of the web, many online publishers have reported seeing their traffic drop alongside the introduction of Google's AI Overviews, raising the spectre of a "Google zero" future where searches no longer send any clicks to the websites that rely on them.

Google claims people are "visiting a greater diversity of websites" from AI overviews and says the people who click through them are more likely to spend more time on the sites they visit.

title: Surfer twice bitten by shark chasing seal off Kangaroo Island
text:
A surfer who survived a shark attack off South Australia's Kangaroo Island drove himself to hospital after being bitten.

Footage believed to be of the attack about 1.30pm yesterday captures the moment chaos unfolded near a popular surf break, known as The Sewer, at D'Estrees Bay.﻿

According to Shark Watch SA, a community shark monitoring site, the predator, believed to be a bronze whaler, was chasing a seal in the lead-up to the incident.

Footage believed to be of the attack about 1.30pm yesterday captures the moment chaos unfolded near a popular surf break (Nine)

D'Estrees Bay on Kangaroo Island. (Wikipedia)

It was reported the seal used the surfer as a decoy before the man was bitten.

﻿The surfer, aged in his 50s, was bitten twice and suffered non-life-threatening injuries.

Bronze whaler sharks can grow to a maximum weight of ﻿300kg and up to 3.3m in length.

title: Geelong Cats fined by AFL over third-party disclosures
text:
The AFL has fined Geelong tens of thousands of dollars after an audit into six years' worth of player payments.

The league said the audit relating to the total player payment (TPP) limit and the soft cap limit from 2019 through 2024 found the club did not breach the TPP or player movement rules.

But it did find "a series of non-disclosures and/or late disclosures of arrangements with club associates and third parties, that were required to be reported to the AFL".

The Cats have been fined $77,500, with $40,000 of it suspended for two years, pending that no future disclosure breaches are found.

Loading

title: Kerr finally set for Matildas return, Fowler on track for Asian Cup
text:
After two long and trying years, Sam Kerr will finally return to the pitch for the Matildas, for this month's friendlies against Wales and England in the UK.

Matildas coach Joe Montemurro has all but confirmed she will be included in the squad, which will be named on Friday.

Kerr's comeback from the ACL injury she sustained in January 2024 kicked off three weeks ago for her club side Chelsea.

She's played limited minutes in her four consecutive WSL matches off the bench, and Montemurro said she will be eased back into international football.

"It's great to see her back. I've had a few discussions with her and I think the great thing is that she's really got an enthusiasm and a real passion back for the game," he said.

"We'll definitely do the right thing by her in terms of integrating her.

Kerr in action recently for Chelsea, on the comeback trail from an ACL injury. (Getty Images/Chelsea FC: Harriet Lander )

"She hasn't played 90 minutes yet. So we'll just see getting closer to camp what sort of minutes we believe is gonna be the best for her so that we make this return perfect both from a football and a mental perspective."

The 32-year-old's last appearance for the Matildas was in November 2023, and it has been an eventful period for the team and her personally since then.

She missed the Australians' underwhelming Paris Olympics campaign that ended at the group stage, was found not guilty of racially harassing a police officer, and welcomed a baby with partner Kristie Mewis.

The West Australian trained with the squad during the last two camps at home, but is yet to play under Montemurro, who started his tenure in June.

And he has not decided whether she will reclaim the captaincy from Steph Catley.

Kerr has trained with the Matildas in their last two camps this year. (Getty Images: Paul Kane)

"Integrating her is the first and foremost thing and to be honest I haven't had a discussion about it," he said.

"The focus has been getting the squad to a point where we want and everyone's on board with that. The captaincy will be assessed once we get closer to the first game."

Mary Fowler on track

Mary Fowler's recovery from her own ACL injury, sustained in April, continues to take massive strides.

Mary Fowler recently re-signed with Manchester City until 2027. (Manchester City)

While Kerr was sidelined for 20 months, the 22-year-old Manchester City forward is targeting a return in less than half that time, with March's Asian Cup in Australia the firm focus.

"Hopefully at the end of the year we'll see her getting some game time at City," Montemurro said.

"They're at that crucial point now where they're probably starting to push her a little bit more [in her recovery], which is great.

"I'll be going to visit actually next week. But she's travelling really well and fingers crossed the Asian Cup is looking really, really positive from that perspective."

Time for stabilising

Montemurro is using the UK games as an "identification camp", aiming to virtually finalise his Asian Cup squad ahead of the last international window of the year in November.

"I still wanna have a look at whether they fit the way we wanna play and how we're gonna approach the Asian Cup," he said.

Montemurro has a short time to get the team ready for the Asian Cup. (Getty Images: Darrian Traynor)

"But I will be stabilising a lot of the the ideas in terms of in terms of patterns, the way we want to play."

While most of the Matildas' top talent is based overseas and the A-League women's season kicking off at the end of October, Montemurro has assured that domestic players will be given due consideration.

"I don't want to punish anyone because they've decided to stay in the A-League and the national team is far away," he said.

"I don't wanna take that attitude. The attitude is what's best for the Matildas to go forward and obviously what's best for the athlete to be at their best.

"And whether it's staying in the A-League or going overseas, I just say be in the best high performance situation that you could be."

title: Outback athlete shares journey to ironman world championship
text:
Broken Hill nurse Bella Kolinac is one of 35 Australian women headed to Hawaii to compete in the Ironman World Championship — Women on October 11.

The course involves a 3.8-kilometre swim along the Kona coastline, a 180-kilometre bike ride through lava fields, finishing with a 25.6-kilometre run.

The idea first came to the 23-year-old years earlier when she first met her partner.

Isaac Sullivan, 30, had been throwing around the idea of entering a triathlon, and Kolinac wanted to go a step further.

"Originally, I said I wanted to start with a full Ironman. He thought that was insane," she said.

Bella Kolinac is representing Australia at the Ironman World Championship — Women. (ABC Broken Hill: Coquohalla Connor)

Mr Sullivan instead implored her to work towards the goal over smaller increments, which she managed to do while working full-time.

"I trained an average of 16 hours a week and then the last couple of weeks I did a 20-hour week. I was getting up at 4am and doing crazy hours," Kolinac said.

Despite a packed training schedule, Kolinac did not believe she would qualify for the Ironman competition and remembered feeling shocked when she realised she had made it through.

Kolinac qualified for the international competition in May in Port Macquarie, where she placed second, securing the 31st qualifying position for Kona.

Bella Kolinac rides for hours at a time, often with no music. (ABC Broken Hill: Coquohalla Connor)

Mr Sullivan remembered feeling a bit hesitant at first, but he quickly became Kolinac's biggest supporter.

"You can be that person that tears someone's dreams down and be negative, but with Bells, seeing her passion and drive … [it made me] actually look at it and go, 'All right, how do we do this? How do we make this happen?'" he said.

Since qualifying in May, Kolinac switched from full-time work to casual so she could dedicate more time to training, and also hired a trainer.

Bella Kolinac recently rode to Menindee and back. (Supplied: Bella Kolinac)

Her training changes from week to week, with her trainer timetabling her long runs, rides, swims and rest.

"Saturday is usually like my long brick session day, so I'll do a six-hour ride with a one-hour run. Then on Sunday will be a long run, usually two to three hours, with a swim or a ride," she said.

The weather in Broken Hill can be hampering.

In recent weeks, when Kolinac was ramping up her training, high winds with raised dust caused a bit of a road bump, including when she rode her bike to Menindee, a 224-kilometre round trip.

"It was 35 kilometres per hour winds, and it was all cross winds, so it was just hitting me, and I'm literally burned from all the half side of me," she said.

Once Bella Kolinac gets into the zone, there is no stopping her. (Supplied: Bella Kolinac)

When the weather is particularly bad, she spends hours on her stationary bike at home.

"The recent couple of 6-hour rides that I've had I've done on the trainer indoors because the weather has been shocking," she said.

"I've done it with no music, no TV or anything, it's just me staring at a wall."

Crossing the line

Kolinac said she was not too worried about the course distances in Hawaii, but the weather and the possibility of a flat tyre ruining her chances were front of mind.

"I think it's going to be crazy hot. I'm so stressed about that," she said.

"[When] I did Western Sydney, the half Ironman, I got three flat tyres. I was literally on the side of the road crying."

Bella Kolinac competed in the Western Sydney Triathlon in September. (Supplied: Bella Kolinac)

Kolinac said she was up for the challenge and eager to connect with other competitors.

"The vibe from everybody watching, it's just so nice," she said

Mr Sullivan said he was emotional just thinking about her crossing the finish line.

"You see a lot of people break down on the line, they've given it their all," he said.

Bella Kolinac celebrates her achievements with Isaac Sullivan. (Supplied: Bella Kolinac)

After Kona, Kolinac said she was planning to take a break before warming up for her next challenge.

"I want to get back to having fun with it, and then maybe next year I'll look at doing the T100 race, which is in the Gold Coast," she said.

Mr Sullivan said he was eager for Kolinac to have a rest first.

"It's super fatiguing ... not just physically, but mentally as well," he said.

"She's not a stopper type of person, so she will not stop, but she'll definitely take it back from a 20-hour week, probably down to about a four-hour week."

title: Mining giant gets $600m worth of taxpayer funds to keep refinery open
text:
Australian taxpayers will fund a multi-million-dollar rescue package for mining giant Glencore to keep copper processing facilities operational in Queensland until the end of 2028.

Glencore has accepted $600 million in financial bridging support for its Mount Isa Copper Smelter, and adjoining Townsville Refinery, from the state and federal governments.

The Swiss multinational warned the copper assets would transition into care and maintenance mode without government support to rebrick the smelter infrastructure, triggering nearly five-month-long negotiations.

50 per cent cost share

Federal Minister for Industry and Innovation Tim Ayres confirmed the package was a 50 per cent cost share between the Commonwealth and state governments.

"The package has a two-year component which is two lots of $200 million, and the third year will be delivered contingent on all of the parties to this arrangement complying with their obligations," Mr Ayres said.

Glencore Metals Australia interim chief operating officer Troy Wilson said the agreement provided a short-term lifeline for the copper smelter and refinery.

"[It] comes after Glencore had already stepped up to absorb significant financial losses to maintain operations and jobs while working on a solution with government," Mr Wilson said.

"On behalf of Glencore and our workers, I would like to express thanks to the Australian and Queensland governments for backing the region and these strategic assets with a critical support package."

Robbie Katter says the package "is a start". (Supplied: Katter's Australian Party)

Katter says 'more needed'

State Member for Traeger Robbie Katter said the funding was good news, but there was still work to be done.

"Let's be clear, we're only at half time. There's no champagne and celebrations at half time, just a rev up from the coach to go out and finish the job in the premiership half," Mr Katter said.

"The federal government in particular have recognised the strategic importance of keeping the smelter operating, and we need them to remain at the negotiating table to reform the smelter operations, not just continually save it and leaving it in the hands of the one owner."

Molten copper being poured into an anode at the Mount Isa Mines Copper Smelter. (Supplied: Glencore)

Region relieved

The Mount Isa smelter processes Glencore and third-party copper-concentrate, which is transported by rail and exported through the Townsville port via the Townsville refinery.

The Townsville refinery processes up to 300,000 tonnes of pure copper cathode each year — a raw material used for copper wire and cabling.

The Mount Isa Copper Smelter requires rebricking every four years, with 60,000 refractory bricks replaced, which was due in 2026.

The last multi-million-dollar rebrick was completed in 2022, and in 2016, the then Labor state government invested $15 million, out of the $30 million required, to rebrick the infrastructure.

Glencore said it directly employed about 600 workers across the Townsville refinery and Mount Isa smelter.

But peak-economy lobby group Townsville Enterprise (TEL), said the company was tied to thousands more jobs indirectly.

The outback mining town of Mount Isa is more than 1,800 kilometres north west of Brisbane. (ABC North West Qld: Meghan Dansie)

"There are about 17,000 jobs at risk if these operations were to cease," TEL Chair Kevin Gill said.

"The by-product from the smelter — sulphuric acid — is transported to the Phosphate Hill fertiliser plant, which is sent on the railway from Mount Isa to the Port of Townsville and shipped out of the port."

He said the Mount Isa smelter was the only facility in Australia that could process third-party copper-concentrate.

"There is a lot of copper that second and third-tier miners are keen to mine, and they do rely on this smelter as well as the refinery and port."

Copper costs

In its bid for government support, Glencore said its smelter and refinery were strategically important assets for Australia, but were uneconomic for the company.

It said refining charges had dropped dramatically as China and Indonesia built their smelting capacity.

Glencore said energy costs in Queensland's north-west were double or more than those in India, China, Canada and the United States.

About 60,000 of the smelter's bricks were replaced over six weeks in 2022. (Supplied: Mount Isa Mines)

The Australian Strategic Policy Institute's (ASPI) Northern Australia lead Dr John Coyne said government support for Glencore should be a hand-up, rather than a handout.

"At the end of the day, the long-term predictions for copper are great, demand will increase," Dr Coyne said.

"Competition in the market is being distorted, with smelters in China being given cheap loans and access to inexpensive power.

"Finally, if we don't protect at least some of our industry, we will lack the ability to support ourselves, in terms of national resilience."

title: Minjee Lee chases more prizes in Asian golf swing
text:
Australian golf superstar Minjee Lee returns to LPGA Tour action for the all-important Asian swing chasing a swag of prestigious awards including one rare golden double.

After a runner-up showing at the Hana Financial Group Championship in Korea, Lee will tee it up at this week's Buick LPGA Shanghai with much at stake heading towards next month's rich season finale in Florida.

Having already wrapped up major player-of-the-year honours, Lee is sitting second behind Thailand's world number one Jeeno Thitikul in the overall player-of-the-year race with seven tournaments remaining.

The world number four has thrust herself into contention for the stellar double after capturing a third career major at the Women's PGA Championship in June while also finishing tied for third behind fellow Australian Grace Kim at the Evian Championship three weeks later in France.

Lee is bidding to become the first Australian since the great Karrie Webb in 1999 and 2000 to be crowned international women's golf's player of the year.

The 29-year-old also tops the LPGA Tour's official money list with $US3,629,430 ($5.51 million) in season earnings — some $US490,000 ($744,343) ahead of Thitikul — after boasting a super consistent six top-five finishes, seven top 10s and 14 top 20 results from 19 events in 2025.

In addition to more awards on offer, Lee is also well positioned in the mega-money, season-long Race to CME Globe standings.

The Perth ace is second behind Thitikul, with the top 60 qualifying for the season-ending Tour Championship in Naples from November 20-23.

The winner of the Tour Championship will pocket $US4 million ($6.08 million), the biggest prize in women's golf history.

After nabbing her maiden major this year, Kim is running 29th on the points list, while fellow Australian Steph Kyriacou (44th) is also on track to qualify for the $US11 million ($16.71 million) season showpiece.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

After a lean season, world number 17 Hannah Green is in 54th spot, with LPGA Tour rookie Cassie Porter (58th) and Gabriela Ruffels (65th) needing a strong next month to secure spots at the Tour Championship.

Kyriacou, Porter, Ruffels and Thitikul all join Lee in this week's field in Shanghai, where China's world number seven Ruoning Yin is the defending champion.

Lee, Thitikul and Yin will play the first two rounds together on Thursday and Friday.

Other Australians featuring are Robyn Choi (67th in the points race), Karis Davidson (82nd), Hira Naveed (112th).

World number two Nelly Korda and number three Lydia Ko are sitting out the event.

AAP

title: Bibbulmun Track record broken twice in one week
text:
The Bibbulmun Track is one of the world's longest walking trails, winding 1,000 kilometres through Western Australia, from Albany on the south coast to Kalamunda in the Perth Hills.

Aaron Young ran about 110 kilometres each day, averaging 3 hours' sleep, to break the record for completing the track in the fastest time, in 9 days, 3 hours and 22 minutes.

"You have high moments where you're feeling alright and you're running well," Mr Young said.

"Throughout the process there are low moments where you feel like taking the next step is pretty difficult, but you just … keep moving forward."

Aaron Young is one of two men who broke the record for running the Bibbulmun Track just days apart. (Supplied: Aaron Young)

Major achievement

But less than two days later, Mr Young's time was beaten by Mackenzie Burgoyne, who finished the track in 8 days, 20 hours and 44 minutes.

Mr Burgoyne is now awaiting his record time to be ratified.

Both were focused on beating the previous record of 10 days and 18 hours, set in 2021.

"Having Aaron start that couple of days before me was something that added a little bit of tension, I won't lie," Mr Burgoyne said.

"We were roughly hitting 110 [kilometres] a day, some were up a little bit, some were down a little bit, but the final push, knowing that Aaron had finished so quick, was 150km a day, over about 26 hours."

Despite the competition, there was also a sense of shared achievement after months of preparation.

The Bibbulmun Track stretches 1,000 kilometres from Kalamunda in Perth's east to Albany in the Great Southern. (Datawrapper)

"We both got to achieve something that we've been working towards for a long time, and the entire WA running community came together for both of us to achieve these goals, which was an incredible experience to be a part of," Mr Burgoyne said.

"We didn't have a prior relationship, but got to know each other quite well throughout this journey over the last few months in preparation and I think now it's safe to say have tremendous respect for one another."

That was also seen on the track.

"I actually went to see Mac on the trail not long before he finished to wish him well for the last little bit," Mr Young said.

Mackenzie Burgoyne says the two men have developed mutual respect for each other after completing the feat. (Supplied: Mackenzie Burgoyne)

Next challenge

Mr Young decided to take on the challenge to raise funds for mental health charity This is A Conversation Starter after experiencing his own challenges.

"In 2016, I tore my ACL [anterior cruciate ligament] in my left knee and over the next … 15 months, while I was waiting for surgery and then during the rehab, I found myself in a situation where my mental health was in the toilet," he said.

"It was when I actually reached out to someone and got a bit of help that I started to get myself back on the right track, and it led me back down the path of fitness."

He already has his eye on another major run.

"I've got a friend of mine who I'm planning to run the Heysen Trail with in South Australia," Mr Young said.

Aaron Young raised funds for a mental health charity. (Supplied: Aaron Young)

"That's a 1,200km trail that runs from … central SA, down past Adelaide and along the coast there."

In the meantime, Mr Young was back at TAFE a day after the feat, studying for his carpentry apprenticeship.

title: Brewer stages beer boycott over Kangaroo Island ferry's 'ridiculous' fares
text:
The owner of Kangaroo Island Brewery will no longer supply beer to Sealink ferries to protest the high cost of travelling to and from the popular tourism destination.

Mike Holden said he made the decision after continually hearing from tourists that they could not afford to revisit the island, located off the southern coast of South Australia.

"All those conversations — they say, 'Kangaroo Island's amazing but I'm not going to come back again' or 'I can't come back because it's simply too expensive,'" he said.

"This is what we hear over and over and over again."

Mr Holden said he believed the cost of more than $800 for a return ferry journey for a family of five with a vehicle was too much for many people.

He said while he did not not have a problem with Sealink "as a company", he no longer wanted to be aligned with them.

The new ferries expected in 2026 will have 150 metres of additional vehicle space. (ABC South East SA: Caroline Horn)

Mr Holden said the whole system needed to be changed and that having a private company in charge of ferry services was "not working".

"We are spending so much on freight, so much on just moving around this 15-kilometre stretch of water, that it's becoming ridiculous and untenable," he said.

"It's hard for everyone to stick their head up and have a bit of a crack at Sealink because no one wants to bite the hand that feeds you."

A Sealink spokesperson told the ABC they valued the Kangaroo Island business community and were "naturally disappointed" by Mr Holden's decision.

But the company said it would continue to work closely with many businesses on the island to promote the region and showcase its experiences and products.

Mayor calls for subsidies

Kangaroo Island Mayor Michael Pengilly said while he doubted the state government would ever take over the running of the ferry service, the council had long called for the implementation of subsidies similar to those available to people travelling to Tasmania.

Michael Pengilly says the council had been lobbying for years funding subsidies for ferry fares. (ABC South East SA: Caroline Horn)

Under the federal government's Bass Strait Passenger Vehicle Equalisation Scheme, passengers can claim rebates of up to $550 per car and $1,104 for cars and caravans.

Around $53.9 million was spent under the scheme in the 2024/25 financial year.

"Unfortunately for us, Tasmania's got a heap of federal seats and federal senators … we're part of a federal seat and a state seat and have only got a population of 4,500," Mr Pengilly said.

Two-year ferry delay

Sealink was awarded the contract to continue to provide ferry services to the island until at least 2039 in 2021.

At the time, it announced plans for two new ferries, with 150 metres more vehicle space each, to be operating by 2024.

That date was later revised to June 2025, with the ferries being built in an Indonesian shipyard.

But the ferries are yet to arrive.

The two new ferries are being constructed in Indonesia. (Supplied: Sealink)

Infrastructure and Transport Minister Emily Bourke announced last week that work on the $73 million upgrades to the wharves at Cape Jervis and Penneshaw were complete.

The work was undertaken to accommodate the larger ferries.

She said the delay to the delivery of the new ferries was "disappointing" but that Sealink had guaranteed they would be operating by June 1, 2026.

Cheaper fares for locals will also be in place from November, along with additional daily crossings until the new ferries and their schedules are in place.

Sealink said it expected the first of its new ferries to be delivered to Port Adelaide by the end of year.

title: Increasing rent driving people away from employment
text:
Australian renters are paying on average an extra $204 per week to keep a roof over their heads compared to five years ago, representing an increase of nearly 44 per cent.

Packed inspections, skyrocketing rents and a fear of price hikes are leaving renters intimidated as vacancy rates plummet to record lows, a report shows.

The median cost to put a roof over your head in a capital city has surged 44 per cent in five years to top $700 per week for the first time, Cotality (formerly CoreLogic) says in its Quarterly Rental Review.

Only 1.47 per cent – or roughly one in every 68 properties – are available to lease, which is less than half the pre-COVID average.

Limited listings and packed inspections are pressuring renters to apply for unsuitable properties or to outbid to get their foot in the door, according to Leo Patterson Ross of the Tenants' Union of NSW.

Leo Patterson Ross says rental prices are driving people away from their jobs and communities. (ABC News: Greg Bigelow)

"With these large groups trying to inspect the same place, it's very intimidating," he said.

" So people are being kind of pushed out further and further away from employment, from their communities, and all of that is very disruptive. "

Renters fear repair requests

Mr Patterson Ross said many renters were not reporting repair needs due to fears landlords would bump rents further.

Australia's $127,000 housing affordability question Photo shows Man looking at for sale sign for apartment. The national project to fix housing affordability is off to a slow start but the reasons are complex.

"You're trying to avoid a rent increase or having to move house in a really competitive market, so it all puts pressure on throughout the tenancy experience," he said.

Reforms to ban no-cause evictions and limit the frequency of rental hikes have been broadly implemented across Australian jurisdictions, but only the ACT has developed an "excessive rent increase" guideline linked to the consumer price index (CPI).

"In other essential areas, like water or energy, we put in pricing structures to make sure that the community is getting a fair deal," Mr Patterson Ross said.

"We haven't done that in renting."

Roughly one in three Australian households rent their home, according to census figures.

Sydney remains the most unaffordable city to live in, with a median price of $807 a week, followed by Perth ($729) and Brisbane ($696).

Hobart was the least expensive at $584 per week, the Cotality report found.

Darwin rental prices in Darwin rose by almost eight per cent, or an extra $49 to $687 per week at the median, which was the nation's largest increase.

Melbourne recorded the slightest increase at 1.4 per cent to a median price of $615.

Regional rents were comparatively more affordable at $591 per week but were up by 5.9 per cent in the year to September compared with 3.7 per cent in the capitals and 4.3 per cent nationally, Cotality economist Kaytlin Ezzy said.

Kaytlin Ezzy says rising rents could impact interest rates. (Supplied: Cotality)

"Limited supply continues to be a major catalyst in rising rents, with the number of rental listings tracking approximately 25 per cent below the previous five-year average nationally for this time of year," she said.

Ms Ezzy said price growth was easing for certain goods but surging rents could complicate the outlook for further interest rate cuts.

"With 'rents paid' a key component of the CPI, the increased pace of rental value growth seen in recent months could push inflation higher," she said.

" This renewed momentum in rents may lead to inflation exceeding RBA forecasts, which could keep the cash rate elevated for longer. "

AAP

title: Federal support for national Aboriginal art gallery in Alice Springs in doubt
text:
The Northern Territory treasurer says the federal government will not support the proposed multi-million-dollar Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art Gallery of Australia (ATSIAGA) in Alice Springs in its current design and location.

Treasurer and infrastructure minister Bill Yan told ABC Alice Springs that without the federal government's financial support the project would be untenable.

The federal government had promised $80 million towards the ATSIAGA, with the NT government contributing $69 million.

Bill Yan has given the federal government a deadline of close of business on Wednesday to decide whether it will maintain its funding commitment. (ABC News: Michael Franchi)

"If the Commonwealth don't put up their $80 million and are not going to support it, then effectively, it's dead in the water,' Mr Yan said.

"I can't go to the territory taxpayer and say I'm going to have to borrow … to deliver on this project."

" This was always a partnership between us and the Commonwealth. "

Mr Yan said he wrote to the federal minister for regional development, Catherine King, Tuesday night asking for a decision by close of business today about whether the funding commitment would be honoured.

The ABC has contacted the federal government for comment.

What happened with the gallery plans?

The project was first announced in 2017 by the former NT Labor government and was set to be built on Anzac Oval.

It was the subject of intense debate over its location, on what traditional owners said was a sacred site.

The Labor government was also criticised for ignoring advice from a committee it set up in 2017 that concluded the gallery should be built out of the town centre, at the Desert Park.

Despite this, the design for the gallery at Anzac Oval was released in 2023, with its open layout and four-level atrium structure touted as its key features.

Loading...

However, in November last year the new CLP government revealed plans to almost halve the size of the art gallery and said it would be moved to the Wills Terrace car park.

The CLP released the new design for the gallery in late July, drawing criticism from residents and federal member for Lingiari Marion Scrymgour as being poorly located and too small to host a gallery of national significance.

On Wednesday, Mr Yan said Ms Scrymgour had been advocating for the project to be moved to a location "south of The Gap" in Alice Springs.

"The benefit then to the CBD and the investment in the CBD effectively disappears … and honestly I can't see the benefit in that."

The new designs of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art Gallery of Australia released in July 2025. (Supplied.)

Alice Springs tourism 'gutted'

Tourism Central Australia CEO Danial Rochford said he was "gutted" to hear the gallery may not go ahead.

Mr Rochford said the loss of the proposed gallery would be devastating for local business and tourism.

Danial Rochford says the potential loss of the proposed gallery will have a huge negative impact on Alice Springs tourism. (ABC News: Xavier Martin )

"This is a project that the tourism industry has seen as a beacon of light, a beacon of opportunity, something that many people have been making decisions in preparation for," he said.

"To hear the news today, words just cannot describe the emotions that we're feeling."

title: Why outback life is the best thing for these kids with cystic fibrosis
text:
Connie Lacey, 4, and Sienna Machin, 10, are like sisters, but they are not allowed to be near each other for long.

"We're supposed to stay away from each other but we're friends, so it's hard," Sienna said.

"If we're really close to each other, we might get sick."

Connie and Sienna have a special bond. (ABC Western Qld: Grace Nakamura)

Both girls have cystic fibrosis (CF) and live in the outback community of Longreach, population 3,647.

Their families have known each other for years so it was bittersweet when Connie was diagnosed with CF, a few years after Sienna.

"We were the only people that the [Laceys] knew that were on the same journey," Sienna's mother, Brooke Machin said.

"We are grateful to have someone else to understand that is close by — it can feel very lonely otherwise."

Brooke Machin travels with Sienna to Brisbane for her treatments. (ABC Western Qld: Grace Nakamura)

More people with CF staying rural

Despite being 1,200 kilometres from the Queensland Children's Hospital, both families say they would not dream of relocating to Brisbane.

"Living out here, people think it impacts our access to health care but that's definitely not been the case," Ms Machin said.

Longreach is 1,177 kilometres away from Brisbane. (Datawrapper: Grace Nakamura)

Cystic fibrosis is a chronic genetic condition that primarily affects the lungs, pancreas, and digestive system.

It is a complex and incurable life-limiting disease.

However, Cystic Fibrosis Queensland CEO Petrina Fraccaro said advancements in treatments had allowed more people with CF to live in rural and regional areas.

"People used to have to attend clinic appointments four to five times a year, and any hospitalisation could be from one to four weeks in duration," Ms Fraccaro said.

"Now, people only have to come to clinic once, maybe twice, a year.

" That's reduced a lot of the burden of the disease … which is wonderful news for allowing families to remain in their local communities. "

Outback air and care

The fresh country air has almost been a treatment itself for the girls.

"City smog" can be problematic for people with CF, who are more susceptible to lung infections.

Starlight's Lookout, a popular view of the outback horizon outside Longreach. (ABC Western Qld: Hannah Walsh)

"The air is dry, there's no humidity, it's a really safe place for Connie to be," Ms Lacey said.

She said the care they received from medical services in Longreach had been "second to none".

"We have … regular telehealth [appointments], plus the Queensland Children's Hospital and Cystic Fibrosis Queensland ensure we still receive the same gold standard of care as if we were living closer to the city," Ms Lacey said.

Connie with her nebuliser that helps her to breathe. (ABC Western Qld: Grace Nakamura)

Ms Machin agrees.

"If we need to go to Brisbane, we jump on a plane and they prioritise us because they know we only have one plane a day," she said.

Travel to Brisbane 'a huge impost'

Despite the benefits, living so far from the capital city has some drawbacks.

Travel from Longreach to Brisbane is expensive and time-consuming.

Ms Machin said they received an allowance from the Patient Travel Subsidy Scheme (PTSS), but the amount has not changed in years.

"Having to go away already has an emotional impact, so that's just an added stress if you have to book accommodation and the price has hiked up," she said.

Sienna Machin travels from Longreach to Brisbane several times a year for her cystic fibrosis. (Supplied: Brooke Machin)

The current PTSS provides $70 a day for accommodation and 34 cents per kilometre travelled, a figure that has not changed since 2013.

In September, Health Minister Tim Nicholls pledged to review the scheme's allowance in next year's state budget.

Ms Fraccaro said the minister's promise was "beyond too little, too late".

"I was very disheartened that he felt this wasn't an urgent matter," she said.

"The provisions covered by that particular subsidy don't even touch the sides of the full cost of a trip to Brisbane for clinic duration."

Improvements over time

For the past 35 years, the Longreach community has turned up for an annual mini marathon to raise funds for cystic fibrosis research.

Horse-riders setting off for the annual Meagan Walker Mini Marathon in Longreach for cystic fibrosis. (Supplied: Meagan Walker Mini Marathon)

The event is named for another local woman, Meagan Walker, who had cystic fibrosis and died at the age of 23.

Her aunt and uncle, Rosemary and Warwick Champion, have been organising the event ever since.

"These little people, Connie and Sienna, have a lot better quality of health than Meagan could ever have dreamt of," Ms Champion said.

She said it gave her hope for continuing improvements in the treatment and quality of life for people with CF.

title: Iron ore mining shows no signs of slowing despite price drop concerns
text:
Mining giants Rio Tinto and BHP are continuing to expand their iron ore foot print in the Pilbara, despite projections indicating long-term demand for the mineral is waning.

On Tuesday, Rio confirmed a $1.1 billion investment for mining new deposits at its West Angelas operations, extending the mine's life "for years to come".

In June it opened a new $2.4 billion iron ore mine near Paraburdoo, and confirmed its investment in mining another major ore deposit with Gina Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting.

Rio Tinto has invested billions of dollars in developing new mining areas in the Pilbara this year. (ABC News: Rachel Pupazzoni)

A day after Rio's West Angelas announcement, WA's environmental watchdog recommended approving a major expansion to BHP's Jimblebar mine.

The investment wave comes at an uncertain time for Australia's iron ore industry, with some industry analysts suggesting the region's title as the world's biggest iron ore supplier could be under threat in the longer term.

Those predictions are being driven by a slowdown in China's building industry, and the emergence of new mines in Brazil and Africa, containing higher-grade iron ore deposits than the Pilbara.

But mining investments consultant Phillip Kirchlechner said the situation was more complicated.

"There's certainly an argument for increasing production [in the Pilbara] as well," he said.

"China has new pillar industries, wind turbines and electric vehicles for example.

" China wants to essentially destroy the German car industry … and so this will constitute, possibly, additional demand for steel in the future that would come out of China. "

Digging deeper

Mr Kirchlechner, who had worked for both Rio Tinto and Fortescue Metals Group, said there was another reason the major miners were looking for new ore deposits.

After 60 years of mining, the Pilbara's highest-grade deposits are gone.

Phillip Kirchlechner says companies are digging deeper to access the Pilbara's highest-grade iron ore deposits. (ABC News: Mietta Adams)

"The low-hanging fruit is already taken, so increasingly you have to mine deeper," Mr Kirchlechner said.

"So there is a scenario of increasing risk as well by having to process the impurities in the iron ore, which are increasing."

Mine rehabilitation scrutiny grows

As the footprint of the Pilbara iron ore industry grows, so too does the environmental scrutiny of their operations.

The WA Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) approval of the Jimblebar expansion included a comment raising concerns about mining rehabilitation.

When new mines are approved in WA, the companies must commit to returning the impacted areas into a state as close to their original condition as possible.

But the EPA report said there was "limited evidence" that proponents had successfully rehabilitated areas that had been subject to large-scale mining.

Todd Erickson says new methods were needed to improve mining rehabilitation. (Supplied: Todd Erickson)

The EPA said it would renew its focus on rehabilitation when assessing future mining proposals.

University of Western Australia senior research fellow Todd Erickson said the commentary was surprising.

The plant ecologist has helped lead multiple rehabilitation projects with both BHP and Rio Tinto, with some small-scale success.

He acknowledged the low rates of rehabilitation were "pretty hard to swallow".

"Any mine rehabilitation in a dry hot desert is quite complex, just because of the given environment," Dr Erickson said.

Rehabilitation includes re-planting natives like the Mulla Mulla in areas cleared for mining operations. (ABC News: Mietta Adams)

"If mining companies continue to use old practices, they'll most likely get less of a result back."

In a statement, a BHP spokesperson noted the EPA's warning.

"Last financial year, our WAIO [Western Australian Iron Ore] progressive rehabilitation programme completed more than 1,000 hectares of land rehabilitation, with the majority delivered by Traditional Owner rehabilitation contractors," it said.

To date, 14 per cent of the 149,700 hectares of land disturbed by BHP's mining operations has been rehabilitated.

Rio Tinto chose not to comment on the EPA's statement.

title: Mistakes costly for Arsenal as trio of Matildas feature in Champions League
text:
Two individual errors have led to Arsenal's Women's Champions League title defence getting off to a losing start in a 2-1 defeat at home to eight-time winners Lyon.

Arsenal's Australian trio of Steph Catley, Caitlin Foord and Kyra Cooney-Cross all featured for the hosts, with Catley playing a full game at Meadow Park and fellow Matildas Foord and Cooney-Cross entering as second-half substitutes.

Gunners goalkeeper Daphne van Domselaar rushed her attempted pass out from the back and picked out Melchie Dumornay just outside her penalty area and the Champions League young player of the year for the last two seasons rolled the ball home at the second attempt.

Van Domselaar also had a hand in the visitors' second in the 23rd minute, although Mariona Caldentey had to shoulder most of the blame.

The goalkeeper rolled the ball out to the Spain midfielder who turned straight into trouble and lost possession, and when Katie Reid's weak header dropped to Dumornay on the edge of the area she fired home.

That undid the ideal start given to them by Alessia Russo in only the seventh minute of this repeat of last season's semifinal.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

Caldentey tried to redeem herself with a 25th-minute volley when the ball dropped to her 20 yards out but her effort was well saved low down by Christiane Endler.

Lyon had the best chance of the second half when Marie-Antoinette Katoto stabbed wide from close range at the near post as Arsenal, who lost their opening game a year ago to Bayern Munich before going on to win the title, struggled to test Endler.

Elsewhere on Tuesday night, Bayern were thrashed 7-1 by three-time champions Barcelona with Ewa Pajor and Claudia Pina scoring doubles.

Cecilia Salvai also bagged a brace for Juventus including an 86th-minute winner at home against Benfica, while European debutants Oud-Heverlee Leuven fought back from two goals down to draw 2-2 at Paris FC.

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AAP/PA

title: I've read 63 books so far this year. Here's how I did it
text:
There's a Japanese word that describes your pile of unread books: tsundoku. It dates back to the 1800s but feels especially relevant today — after all, we're reading less than we used to.

Every demographic has experienced a decline in reading since 2012, according to data from the Household, Income and Labour Dynamics in Australia (HILDA) survey.

Another Deakin University study reveals 29 per cent of Australian teens don't read for fun.

ABC Radio National's Top 100 Books of the 21st Century Top 100 Books is Radio National's new annual countdown where we hand over the reins to you to vote for your favourite books. Celebrate the Top 100 with us in a big weekend broadcast on October 18 and 19!

It's not just an Australian phenomenon: recreational reading is at a 20-year low for Americans, while 40 per cent of Britons haven't finished a book in the past year.

Losing your reading mojo

I knew the slump was bad when an author — during their memoir-promoting tour, no less — admitted their reading had tailed off significantly.

"This is not good material for somebody trying to sell a book," they told me.

I can relate: I've gone through reading droughts throughout my life. I was a voracious bookworm when I was younger but as I aged, I found myself reading less and less.

The pressure to conquer classics and zip through Zeitgeist-capturing books was still there — without the kid-like luxury of losing myself in chapters for endless hours.

Knowing I wouldn't finish every literary masterpiece written only amplified the anxiety.

I once was so overwhelmed by reading choices, I limited myself to what was released in the past 12 months. Even then, I only finished four books a year.

Freelance journalist Lee Tran Lam listens to audiobooks at 2x speed. (Supplied: Will Reichelt)

Only during Christmas holidays (when the to-do list was clear) did I speed through reading streaks. It turns out you can finish a book in a day if you literally have nothing else to do.

These commitment-free conditions are hard to replicate throughout the rest of the year, though. Who has endless days for turning pages when work deadlines surface and bills need paying?

Before I knew it, I was in another reading slump.

How to make reading a habit

I broke one such reading drought with Charles Yu's Interior Chinatown in 2020. I breezed through the entire audiobook in one apartment-cleaning afternoon: a 4-hour blitz that recharged my love of novels instantly.

Interior Chinatown is an inspired exploration of Hollywood Asian stereotypes like Kung Fu Guy, Background Oriental Male and Generic Asian Man. It became one of my favourite books of the year (not that there was much competition).

It was galvanising, too: I could conquer a book in a day and didn't even have to wait until Christmas. I added more audiobooks to my diet.

How to read more Pick up a book before you pick up your phone in the morning — even if it's for five minutes

Lean into shorter formats like graphic novels and poetry collections

Track the books you read using an app or a spreadsheet

Listen to audiobooks at 1.5x or 2x speed

Join the library to access free audiobooks and eBooks, as well as old-fashioned paper books

Over time, I've steadily increased my reading volume (even lifting my released-this-year-only restriction) and worked my way through more titles as a result.

I started listing everything I finished in a spreadsheet, a handy reference when friends asked for recommendations. Adding another publication to the "finished" column was a satisfying achievement.

Other people prefer book-tracking apps (like StoryGraph or Bookshelf) or triumphantly post completed stacks on Instagram or TikTok.

With social media's algorithmic pull becoming ever stronger, I try to counteract the empty-calorie sensation of "feeling too online" by turning to books instead.

I start each morning with 5 minutes of something, maybe an eBook on my phone or audiobook on my iPad, and flick through pages of a physical volume later in the day.

And this year, without trying, I've finished more books than ever in a single year: 63 so far in 2025.

Use your library card

Yes, I've turned to short volumes of poetry (Mosab Abu Toha's unshakeable Forest Of Noise) and graphic novels (Venice, Jiro Taniguchi's nostalgic 128-page travel novella).

But what's truly turbocharged my reading is my library card and its 24/7 access to free apps like Libby and BorrowBox.

My reading appetite had previously been held back by my book-buying budget (which is much smaller than I'd like), but thanks to the library, I'm now more voracious and adventurous with what I seek out.

My audiobook-consuming tempo is now a step faster (1.5-2.0 speed at most, fast but not chipmunk-level of unintelligible squeaking).

And instead of tuning into another aimless celebrity podcast, I opt for tightly written memoirs (like the Grammy-winning audiobook version of Viola Davis's autobiography Finding Me, elevating her to EGOT status for good reason).

September's best books Photo shows A composite image of eight book covers pictured on a green background Wondering what to read next? This month's best books include the latest from literary giant Ian McEwan and Buckeye, a multigenerational family saga set in America's Midwest.

I love that reading is a passport to experiencing countless new perspectives, from Katie Goh's memoir told through the history of oranges (Foreign Fruit) to Patrick Bringley's life as a New York museum guard (All the Beauty in the World).

The time pressure of needing to return library books also fast-tracks my reading: I bought Hua Hsu's Stay True in paperback three years ago, but only finished it after checking out the audiobook on BorrowBox in August.

My reading can sometimes lag (it's taken me four months to read 92 pages of Samantha Harvey's Orbital), but rewiring my doomscrolling reflex has made a difference.

Yes, I'm as susceptible to cat memes and viral clips as anyone else, but turning reading into a progressively habitual pastime has led to more completed books.

And the pay-off? It only takes one page to be transported elsewhere.

Tune into ABC Radio National on October 18 and 19 to listen to the Top 100 Books countdown.

title: Neighbour pays tribute to Broncos star Staggs after family heartbreak
text:
Kotoni Staggs says an NRL premiership ring is proof that good things come to kind people, and the Brisbane centre has been showing plenty of kindness to a heartbroken family in his neighbourhood.

Only days before Staggs and his fiancee Britt moved into their new home in 2023, tragedy had struck the family next door as father David Orange died suddenly and unexpectedly.

The fit-and-healthy local business owner was only 38, and left behind wife Kerry and seven-month old daughter, Eylea.

In the family's darkest hour, their new next door neighbour became a shining light.

Staggs often buys the family groceries, drives them places and babysits young Eylea among other acts of kindness, never asking anything in return.

"When somebody needs help and I'm around, and obviously I bump into people like that, I'll do it straight away," Staggs said after the Broncos' 26-22 grand final win over Melbourne.

Staggs with partner Brittany Becht at the 2025 Dally M awards. (Getty Images: Mark Metcalfe)

"I'll go through struggles sometimes but someone else is always going through a bigger struggle than what I am. If I can be there for them and put a smile on their face, that's what I'll do.

"I'll take my shirt off and give it to them. If I had my last hundred dollars, I'd do the same thing. I'm a giver."

Kerry Orange didn't know of Staggs' football career, nor had she even watched an NRL game before meeting him.

Through his generosity, she has come to think of Staggs as a member of the family.

"In the early, fragile days of grief, when even getting through the day felt impossible, Kotoni quietly became a steady and loving presence," Orange said.

"Without being asked, he stepped into our lives like an uncle to Eylea, offering support in the gentlest, most selfless ways.

"He gave both of us something I thought we had lost forever: a sense of peace, moments of comfort and even glimpses of joy in the midst of heartbreak.

"I will be forever grateful for the love and support he's given us."

The 26-year-old Staggs credits his late grandmother, Dawn, for instilling his desire to give back to others.

Staggs did not meet his father until his early 20s and was estranged from his mother for parts of his childhood, so Dawn was his guardian growing up in the NSW town of Wellington.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

He still wears her name on strapping tape on his wrist during games and has a photo of the two of them on his bedside table.

"Without my grandmother, I don't think I'd be walking around here right now. I'd probably be on the streets with no money (or) I'd be locked up," Staggs said.

"She was my everything and she made sure we had food, we had everything on the table. She did what she did and I turned out to be an all right kid."

As Staggs does his best to carry on Dawn's legacy through acts of kindness, good things have begun to happen.

He played centre in the Broncos' first grand final win since 2006 on Sunday night and has since earned selection in Kevin Walters' Kangaroos squad for the Ashes tour.

"I love giving back to people and I love helping out people," he said.

"At the end of the day, when you do good things, good things come in return. This (grand final win) is what happens."

The ABC of SPORT Sports content to make you think... or allow you not to. A newsletter delivered each Saturday.

AAP

title: Taylor Swift shines in Australian-designed dress in lead single
text:
Pop superstar Taylor Swift has worn Adelaide-based label, Paolo Sebastian, in her latest music video, The Fate of Ophelia.

Founder and designer Paul Vasileff told ABC News Breakfast the label had been approached by Swift's team "a while ago".

"I'm just so grateful and so excited to think that something that was made in Adelaide and something that we handcrafted is then seen on a world stage," he said.

The Paolo Sebastian dress from A Lover's Kiss Collection was worn by Taylor Swift in her music video for The Fate of Ophelia. (instagram@paul_vasileff / Paolo Sebastian)

The dress was one of many outfits featured in the newly released music video for The Fate of Ophelia, which is the lead single of Swift's twelfth studio album, The Life of a Showgirl.

Mr Vasileff said he found out about Swift wearing the dress from Paolo Sebastian's 'A Lovers Kiss Collection' when the rest of the world did.

"I was getting onto a plane to come here to Dubai as we found out, and I think I saw the images in the video for like an hour or so and then jumped on the plane and was completely disconnected from everything," he said.

"I was kind of sitting there for 12 hours going, 'I want to see more. I want to know what's going on'."

Taylor Swift wore Adelaide label Paolo Sebastian in her new music video. (Instagram: @taylorswift)

Mr Vasileff is no stranger to dressing celebrities, with people like Kim Kardashian, Katy Perry and recently Rachel Zegler and Anya Taylor-Joy having donned the label.

Just last year, actress Jessica Alba wore one of Mr Vasileff's dresses to the White House — a black French chantilly lace creation draped onto a corset bodice, spraying out into a skirt.

Speaking from Dubai, Mr Vasileff said he was proud to be able to keep the work in SA, and show it off to the world.

"Couture and hand making garments, it's a dying art form, so I'm really proud that it's something that we've been able to keep in South Australia," he said.

"Growing up, I was told to be successful, you're going to have to move overseas or you're not going to be able to do it out of Adelaide.

title: Confidence returns to fickle Australian wool industry as prices surge
text:
After being hit by drought and rising feed and production costs in recent years, some wool growers have been leaving the industry, concerned about their viability.

For those who stuck it out, like Condobolin grower Gabby Neale, the recent sustained run of rising wool prices amid strong demand has given them a reason for optimism.

"There's just so much potential that I think it's worth sticking around," Ms Neale said.

Gabby Neale says the recent Nanjing Wool Market Conference in China was an eyeopener. (Supplied: Nanjing Wool Conference)

Ms Neale grew up on a wool farm in Condobolin and is now the founder and creative director of Merino clothing label Intact.

She said she had always seen great potential for wool beyond traditional knitwear and wanted to ensure consumers continued to find benefit in the homegrown fibre.

"Future success, in any business, comes from innovation through efficiencies and design," Ms Neale said.

Representatives of the Australian wool industry at the AWI Future Wool Industry Leaders tour in China. (Supplied: Kristen Frost)

Recently arriving back from an Australian Wool Innovation (AWI) Future Wool Industry Leaders tour to China, Ms Neale has renewed optimism for the wool sector.

She said being able to see firsthand the value overseas customers put on Australia's wool product was reassuring.

"The biggest takeaway for me was the level of scale and investment the Chinese have put into the industry and how much value they place on Australian wool," she said.

"We all walked away from the trip with the same sentiment that it's not something that's going to go away."

Longest winning run since 80s

China is the largest consumer of Australian wool, buying about 85 per cent of production.

The continued demand for Australian wool at a time when production has been forecast to drop to its lowest level in 100 years has resulted in sustained price increases on the auction floor.

The Australian wool industry's Eastern Market Indicator (EMI) has climbed for 11 consecutive weeks, which is the longest run of price rises since 1987.

Wool industry slump Photo shows A woman in a hat and white shirt stands in a sheep yard. Wool production is forecast to drop to its lowest level in 100 years, but young farmers remain optimistic about the future.

In the NSW New England region, Walcha growers Hugh and Felicity Nivison achieved the top auction price so far this season — an outstanding $190 per kilo.

Mr Nivison said his family's farm had seen many ups and downs across its 90-year history.

"I know a lot of people have decided there's not enough money in merinos and they're getting out and it's nice to see a bit of confirmation that maybe staying in them isn't a bad idea," he said.

Mr Nivison is encouraging more growers to consider staying in the industry, with more diversification.

"You don't really want to follow all the lemmings off the cliff," he said.

"I think there's a solid outlook there for the moment and I think if we keep on producing good wool and be efficient at it and be productive, then I think there's a good reason for staying in them as part of your business."

Harold Manttan with the Nivison family's wool clip that has fetched the highest price for the season so far. (Supplied: Harold Manttan)

'Swings and roundabouts' normal in industry

District wool manager for Elders Dubbo, Lindsay Brown, is another young industry member buoyed by the latest developments.

"From where it's been for the last 12 to 24 months, it's been a real sugar hit for us," Mr Brown said.

" For those people who are still in the game, who have stuck around, I think they'll get rewarded in due course. it just fills you with a bit of confidence with where the market's at. "

Lindsay Brown says the wool industry has always seen highs and lows. (Supplied: Kristen Frost)

He said wool markets had always ebbed and flowed.

"I guess with anything, it always swings and roundabouts with any commodity in any industry," Mr Brown said.

Analyst urges caution as costs remain high

Amid the optimism, wool analyst Matt Dalgleish warned it was too early to say the sector had turned a corner.

He said costs remained high and production was continuing to fall significantly.

"That to me is a signal of industry in distress and contracting rather than a huge growth in demand for wool somehow globally that's underpinning these stronger prices," Mr Dalgleish said.

However, Australian Wool Network's northern NSW and Queensland regional manager, Harold Manttan, said he was confident the uptick in auction room prices would continue.

"Listening to the trade, I'd say it's got some forward motion yet," he said.

" In my 40 years in the game, I haven't seen anything like this really. "

There has been an expected correction to the market this week, with falls seen in southern wool markets at the time of publication.

title: Live: Suns close in on Petracca deal after nabbing prized draft pick
text:
I'd be VERY surprised if Ryley Sanders leaves the Bulldogs for the Crows. He's very at home with us, and we utilise him a lot. But would be keen to hear your thoughts... - Doggies fan

Ryley Sanders' position at the Bulldogs has always been interesting to me.

(Getty Images)

The Dogs were so keen on him in his draft year, but I don't think he's fully won them over with his performances since then. Not enough that they will actively be wishing him out the door, but enough that they wouldn't hang up on Adelaide immediately.

The Dogs would have a couple of thoughts about all this. One is the need for a key defender, which could see Jordan Butts (and picks, of course) be of interest from the Crows. The other is next year's Zak Butters chase, which could see them move for some future picks if Sanders was to leave.

For what it's worth, I really like Sanders and think there's a lot more to come from him. I wouldn't be entertaining trading him if I were at the Dogs, at least not until Tassie come knocking in a couple of years. His value would likely be much higher by then.

title: 'Do you want a player to die?' Heat dominates tennis events in China
text:
Holger Rune has renewed calls for a universal heat rule and Novak Djokovic required treatment as players fought through brutal conditions at the Shanghai Masters on Tuesday.

Rune, the world number 11, was heard to ask "do you want a player to die on court?" during his victory over Ugo Humbert on Sunday, 6-4, 6-7 (7), 6-3 victory over Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard.

"We can handle a certain amount of heat, because we're strong, and mentally strong as well, but there is always a limit," he told reporters after the match.

" It's also important to take care of your health. We need to survive. "

Djokovic, 38, had to take a medical timeout after picking up a leg injury during the first set of an encounter against Jaume Munar that stretched to two hours and 41 minutes.

Djokovic won 6-3 5-7 6-2, but struggled with the heat.

Medics checked his vital statistics at one point as the temperature stayed near 30 degrees Celsius and humidity hovered at about 80 per cent.

Novak Djokovic needed treatment for a leg injury, and heat stress, in Shanghai. (Getty Images: Lintao Zhang)

The Serbian vomited during his match against Yannick Hanfmann on Sunday and world number two Jannik Sinner retired due to cramps.

"It's the same for every player out on the court, but it's brutal," Djokovic said after beating Hanfmann 4-6, 7-5, 6-3.

"It's brutal when you have over 80 per cent of humidity day after day, particularly for the guys when they're playing during the day with heat, with sun, it's even more brutal."

Loading...

Fourth seed Djokovic, who had got the first break of the match to go 3-1 up in the opening set before he hurt his leg, could not break Munar's serve during the second set, which the world number 41 won after a 75-minute battle.

The 24-time grand slam winner bent over in exhaustion and needed more medical attention before clinching the decisive third set with two well-timed breaks.

Djokovic collapsed on the court after winning the match.

He is set to face Zizou Bergs in the last eight.

Earlier on Tuesday, Emma Raducanu retired from her Wuhan Open match against Ann Li after struggling with exhaustion and having her blood pressure checked on a hot and humid afternoon.

Iga Świątek couldn't hide from the heat in China this week. (Getty Images: Robert Prange)

Iga Świątek enjoyed a 6-1 6-1 rout of Marie Bouzková, but noted that conditions the day prior would have been "too much for most of the players".

"I hope the other matches will be scheduled at a time where girls can compete, rather than just die on the court," Swiatek said.

The ATP said it would consider introducing a formal heat rule, as was the case at the Australian Open and other grand slams.

"Every player would agree," that a heat rule should be implemented, Rune said.

In a statement, the ATP said player safety was its highest priority and that on-site medical teams monitored the conditions.

De Minaur focuses on 'surviving'

Meanwhile, seventh-seeded Alex De Minaur defeated Kamil Majchrzak 6-1, 7-5 in humid conditions for his tour-leading 36th win on hard courts this year.

The 26-year-old broke Majchrzak's serve five times to reach the Masters 1000 fourth round for the seventh time this season.

Two of the breaks came after he dropped serve to trail 4-3 in the second set.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"I came into this week knowing how tough the conditions were going to be," De Minaur said.
